Curt Sampson wrote:

> On Tue, 6 Jul 2004, hedgi wrote:
> 
>  >   Now I there is the problem. I want to run "testCommon" first
>  >   which is in the "BasicGetListTest" but when I subclass it with
>  >   "GlucoseGetListTest" it is always executed last. I read some of
>  >   the postings in this newsgroup, but it seems that such kind of
>  >   requirement point a desing flaw and I should somehow rearrange my
>  >   Unit Test Structure to made the tests indepentdant. I'm stuck with
>  >   it.
> 
> I've been thinking for a while that this is a serious problem in JUnit
> (and most unit testing frameworks), because it's been such an annoyance
> for so many people. Let's face it; a lot of groups of tests do have
> known dependencies between tests such that if test A fails, we know that
> the output of tests B, C and D are uninteresting. Yet we end up running
> B, C and D anyway, and then searching through all the error output for
> the failure that we know is the "real" one, ignoring all the others as
> spurious.
> 
> I would really like a way to be able to express this dependency
> information to the test framework, so that I can get back the
> interesting results with fewer uninteresting results. Can anybody
> think of a good way to do this?

One thing you could try is this:

1. Add an abort() method to interface Test that allows a test to be 
aborted. For a test case, this simply fails the test with an "aborted" 
message. For test suites, this causes the suite to stop executing entirely.

2. Express dependencies by building a special OrderedTestSuite class 
that aborts when a test fails. All tests that depend on each other this 
way go into an OrderedTestSuite.

This may require a custom test runner, but that would be a good thing: 
it would mean less clutter in the base test runners.

As for the details, I don't know, since I don't want it yet. :)

Another possibility -- something that may be easier, for now -- is to 
filter the test results based on your dependencies, since that seems to 
be the underlying problem. I think that executing all those tests would 
be interesting, in case doing so uncovers some strange, unexpected 
dependency that you /need/ to fix.
